articles.headline: For the Recently Widowed, Some Big Financial Pitfalls to Avoid
articles.snippet: A spouse dies, and the widow must handle a variety of financial tasks, like investing and paying taxes, when her emotions are raw.
articles.abstract: A spouse dies, and the widow must handle a variety of financial tasks, like investing and paying taxes, when her emotions are raw.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are few more wrenching events in life than losing your spouse.

articles.headline: Federal Regulators Sue Big Banks Over Mortgages
articles.snippet: The action is part of a growing attempt to force banks to pay billions of dollars for helping stoke the housing bubble.
articles.abstract: The action is part of a growing attempt to force banks to pay billions of dollars for helping stoke the housing bubble.
articles.lead_paragraph: A bruising legal fight pitting the country’s most powerful banks against the full force of the United States government began Friday, as federal regulators filed suits against 17 financial institutions that sold the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac nearly $200 billion in mortgage-backed securities that later soured.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Kevin Roose

articles.headline: AT&T Plans to Woo U.S. And Fight It
articles.snippet: AT&T has vowed to do battle with the Justice Department in court while it tries to cozy up to antitrust regulators by agreeing to shed assets and submit to monitoring.
articles.abstract: AT&T has vowed to do battle with the Justice Department in court while it tries to cozy up to antitrust regulators by agreeing to shed assets and submit to monitoring.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — AT&T plans to approach the Justice Department to discuss conditions, including the sale of assets or the transfer of subscribers to other companies, that would allow its merger with T-Mobile to be completed, people close to the transaction said Friday.

articles.headline: Fiat’s Retro Return
articles.snippet: A remake of the postwar Fiat will have to get Americans to forget the low quality of its first incarnation on these shores. So far, it’s working.
articles.abstract: A remake of the postwar Fiat will have to get Americans to forget the low quality of its first incarnation on these shores. So far, it’s working.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — Fiat, the Italian auto company, is getting a rare second chance to make a good first impression among American car buyers. And unlike the disastrous end to its first go-round decades ago, the carmaker has already managed to create a buzz.

articles.headline: The Dog-Eared Paperback, Newly Endangered in an E-Book Age
articles.snippet: The mass-market paperback, the cheap, pocket-size reading material of beaches and airports, is in decline as e-books proliferate and cost-conscious readers rein in their impulse purchases.
articles.abstract: The mass-market paperback, the cheap, pocket-size reading material of beaches and airports, is in decline as e-books proliferate and cost-conscious readers rein in their impulse purchases.
articles.lead_paragraph: These are dark and stormy times for the mass-market paperback, that squat little book that calls to mind the beach and airport newsstands.

articles.headline: Nearly Out of Tricks, Fed May Pare Longer Rates
articles.snippet: The dispiriting employment report again turned eyes toward the Fed. But it was unclear if the economy’s problems were amenable to further monetary salves.
articles.abstract: The dispiriting employment report again turned eyes toward the Fed. But it was unclear if the economy’s problems were amenable to further monetary salves.
articles.lead_paragraph: News that the economy added zero jobs in August raises the chances that the Federal Reserve will announce another round of stimulus when it meets in two weeks, Fed-watchers say, most likely by pushing down long-term interest rates.

articles.headline: Files Note Close C.I.A. Ties to Qaddafi Spy Unit
articles.snippet: Documents at an abandoned office in Tripoli show that Libya’s cooperation with the C.I.A. and its British equivalent, MI-6, was much more extensive than generally known.
articles.abstract: Documents at an abandoned office in Tripoli show that Libya’s cooperation with the C.I.A. and its British equivalent, MI-6, was much more extensive than generally known.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Documents found at the abandoned office of Libya’s former spymaster appear to provide new details of the close relations the Central Intelligence Agency shared with the Libyan intelligence service — most notably suggesting that the Americans sent terrorism suspects at least eight times for questioning in Libya despite that country’s reputation for torture.

articles.headline: Perry’s Blunt Views in Books Get New Scrutiny as He Joins Race
articles.snippet: When Rick Perry, the governor of Texas and a presidential hopeful, debates his rivals, his assertions on climate change, Social Security and health care could put him to the test.
articles.abstract: When Rick Perry, the governor of Texas and a presidential hopeful, debates his rivals, his assertions on climate change, Social Security and health care could put him to the test.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, believes that climate change is a “contrived, phony mess.” The federal income tax was the “great milestone on the road to serfdom.” And the Boy Scouts of America are under attack by “a radical homosexual movement.”

articles.headline: New Urgency in the Battle for Stimulus
articles.snippet: President Obama and Congress on Friday each confronted increasing pressure to shift their focus to job creation.
articles.abstract: President Obama and Congress on Friday each confronted increasing pressure to shift their focus to job creation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Having battled for months over deficit reduction, President Obama and Congress on Friday each confronted new urgency to shift their focus to job creation after the most anemic employment report in many months.

articles.headline: Republican Candidates Turn Attacks on One Another
articles.snippet: The Republican field is entering a pivotal stage as candidates increasingly move beyond criticizing President Obama and start to run against each other.
articles.abstract: The Republican field is entering a pivotal stage as candidates increasingly move beyond criticizing President Obama and start to run against each other.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANOLA, Iowa — Gov. Rick Perry is privately being coached to come across as more presidential — cautious in his comments, deliberate in defending his Texas record — while building on his fast start by trying to consolidate support across the Republican spectrum, from the Tea Party and evangelicals to the party establishment.

articles.headline: O.K., Downloaders, Let’s Try This Song Again
articles.snippet: The ambitions of the Qtrax music site may seem quixotic, but it offers something distinct in today’s market: free and legal downloads.
articles.abstract: The ambitions of the Qtrax music site may seem quixotic, but it offers something distinct in today’s market: free and legal downloads.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE digital music landscape is littered with the corpses of start-ups that tried and failed to offer free music downloads. One of them was Qtrax, which imploded amid controversy and lawsuits a few years ago.

articles.headline: Soldier, Thinker, Hunter, Spy: Drawing a Bead on Al Qaeda
articles.snippet: Michael Vickers’s preoccupation — “my life,” he says — is dismantling Al Qaeda.
articles.abstract: Michael Vickers’s preoccupation — “my life,” he says — is dismantling Al Qaeda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Every day, Michael G. Vickers gets an update on how many in Al Qaeda’s senior leadership the United States has removed from the battlefield, and lately there has been much to report. Al Qaeda’s No. 2 died in a C.I.A. drone strike late last month, another senior commander was taken out in June, and the Navy Seals made history when they dispatched Osama bin Laden in May.

articles.headline: In Classroom of Future, Stagnant Scores
articles.snippet: Schools are embracing digital learning, but evidence is scarce that the expensive technology is improving educational outcomes.
articles.abstract: Schools are embracing digital learning, but evidence is scarce that the expensive technology is improving educational outcomes.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANDLER, Ariz. — Amy Furman, a seventh-grade English teacher here, roams among 31 students sitting at their desks or in clumps on the floor. They’re studying Shakespeare’s “As You Like It” — but not in any traditional way.

articles.headline: Accustomed to Wheels, Thrill-Seeking Injured Veterans Take Wing
articles.snippet: New programs have sprung up offering extreme sports for the disabled, many of them veterans, whose bodies are badly injured but whose souls still crave adventure.
articles.abstract: New programs have sprung up offering extreme sports for the disabled, many of them veterans, whose bodies are badly injured but whose souls still crave adventure.
articles.lead_paragraph: KETCHUM, Idaho — Searching for ways to keep his adrenaline pumping after a motorcycle accident forced him out of the military and into a wheelchair, Darol Kubacz recast himself as something of a pioneer of extreme sports.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Appealing to Palestinians to Stall U.N. Vote
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has initiated a last-ditch diplomatic campaign to avert a confrontation over a plan by Palestinians to seek recognition as a state.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has initiated a last-ditch diplomatic campaign to avert a confrontation over a plan by Palestinians to seek recognition as a state.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has initiated a last-ditch diplomatic campaign to avert a confrontation this month over a plan by Palestinians to seek recognition as a state at the United Nations, but it may already be too late, according to senior American officials and foreign diplomats.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Mark Landler

articles.headline: China Aims to Rein In Car Sales
articles.snippet: Government officials called for the country’s automakers to shift away from making more cars and toward producing more fuel-efficient and technologically advanced ones.
articles.abstract: Government officials called for the country’s automakers to shift away from making more cars and toward producing more fuel-efficient and technologically advanced ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — After a decade of nurturing China’s auto industry to become the largest in the world, this country’s leaders are having second thoughts.

articles.headline: Postal Service Is Nearing Default as Losses Mount
articles.snippet: The agency is so low on cash that it will not be able to make a $5.5 billion payment due this month and may have to shut down entirely this winter unless Congress acts to stabilize its finances.
articles.abstract: The agency is so low on cash that it will not be able to make a $5.5 billion payment due this month and may have to shut down entirely this winter unless Congress acts to stabilize its finances.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States Postal Service has long lived on the financial edge, but it has never been as close to the precipice as it is today: the agency is so low on cash that it will not be able to make a $5.5 billion payment due this month and may have to shut down entirely this winter unless Congress takes emergency action to stabilize its finances.

articles.headline: In California, Amazon Pushes Hard to Kill a Tax
articles.snippet: To avoid paying tens of millions of dollars, Amazon.com is seeking a voter referendum on whether online retailers should pay sales taxes.
articles.abstract: To avoid paying tens of millions of dollars, Amazon.com is seeking a voter referendum on whether online retailers should pay sales taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The struggling state of California thinks it has found gold in taxing e-commerce. But that money is proving much more elusive than it seemed just a few months ago.

articles.headline: Neither Smurf Nor Wizard Could Save Summer Movie Attendance
articles.snippet: Hollywood has now experienced four consecutive summers of falling attendance, a cause for alarm for both studios and theater chains.
articles.abstract: Hollywood has now experienced four consecutive summers of falling attendance, a cause for alarm for both studios and theater chains.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was the summer that North American movie attendance continued to slide, Hollywood’s reliance on overseas ticket sales intensified, the Smurfs flexed their minimuscles and a cadre of A-list stars flopped — again.

articles.headline: Discharged for Being Gay, Veterans Seek to Re-enlist
articles.snippet: With the looming repeal of “don’t ask, don’t tell” comes a surge of interest from some of the thousands of service members pushed out under the policy.
articles.abstract: With the looming repeal of “don’t ask, don’t tell” comes a surge of interest from some of the thousands of service members pushed out under the policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: They lived shadow lives in the military, afraid that disclosure of their sexuality would ruin carefully plotted careers. Many were deeply humiliated by drawn-out investigations and unceremonious discharges.

articles.headline: Libyans Turn Wrath on Dark-Skinned Migrants
articles.snippet: Libyan rebels have imprisoned hundreds of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa, accusing them of being mercenaries for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
articles.abstract: Libyan rebels have imprisoned hundreds of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa, accusing them of being mercenaries for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — As rebel leaders pleaded with their fighters to avoid taking revenge against “brother Libyans,” many rebels were turning their wrath against migrants from sub-Saharan Africa, imprisoning hundreds for the crime of fighting as “mercenaries” for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi without any evidence except the color of their skin.

articles.headline: A Tech Blogger Who Leaps Over the Line
articles.snippet: When Michael Arrington, the editor of TechCrunch, formed a company to finance some of the start-ups his site writes about, he stepped over the line.
articles.abstract: When Michael Arrington, the editor of TechCrunch, formed a company to finance some of the start-ups his site writes about, he stepped over the line.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Michael Arrington, the editor of the popular Web site TechCrunch, told his bosses at AOL that he was forming a venture capital company to finance some of the technology start-ups that his site wrote about, they did not fire him or ask for his resignation. Instead, last week, they invested about $10 million in his fund.

articles.headline: A Debate Arises on Job Creation and Environment
articles.snippet: Economists say regulations must be judged by economic and social factors as well as environmental priorities.
articles.abstract: Economists say regulations must be judged by economic and social factors as well as environmental priorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Do environmental regulations kill jobs?
articles.byline: By MOTOKO RICH and JOHN BRODER

articles.headline: All-American, Floor to Roof? Not So Simple
articles.snippet: Anders Lewendal, a general contractor in Montana, thinks building houses with only American-made materials would help revive the construction industry. But it is not as easy as it sounds.
articles.abstract: Anders Lewendal, a general contractor in Montana, thinks building houses with only American-made materials would help revive the construction industry. But it is not as easy as it sounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOZEMAN, Mont. — Anders Lewendal, a general contractor who managed to survive the housing collapse, has hit upon a plan that he thinks will revive the construction industry and help lead the nation out of the economic wilderness: build houses using only American-made materials.

articles.headline: Media Strive to Cover 9/11 Without Seeming to Exploit a Tragedy
articles.snippet: In documenting the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, media outlets have followed different paths in covering a solemn occasion that is also a business opportunity.
articles.abstract: In documenting the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, media outlets have followed different paths in covering a solemn occasion that is also a business opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anniversaries are hard to resist for most media outlets. The stories are evergreen, the advertising potential plentiful.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Banks Lead Sharp Declines in Global Shares
articles.snippet: European and Asian markets continue to worry about the health of the United States economy and about the amount of capital available to banks.
articles.abstract: European and Asian markets continue to worry about the health of the United States economy and about the amount of capital available to banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Fears of a new financial crisis and worries about the health of the United States economy sent share prices tumbling in Europe on Monday and also led to declines in Asia. Markets in the United States were closed for the Labor Day holiday, but sharp declines in the overseas trading of stock index futures indicated the sell-off was likely to continue on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By David Jolly and Bettina Wassener

articles.headline: Europeans Talk of Sharp Change in Fiscal Affairs
articles.snippet: While many of the ideas have yet to hit official agendas, officials say there has been a substantial step-up in planning for a closer European fiscal relationship.
articles.abstract: While many of the ideas have yet to hit official agendas, officials say there has been a substantial step-up in planning for a closer European fiscal relationship.
articles.lead_paragraph: As leaders in Europe try to contain a deepening financial crisis, they are also increasingly talking about making fundamental changes to the way their 17-nation economic union works.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Matthew Saltmarsh
